text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full-page miniature within red and gold frame; no integration of running text, image occupies entire recto; text visible only as recto-verso bleed-through but not part of design.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for throne, crown, and frame to signify royal authority; ultramarine and vermilion used to differentiate principal figures (king in blue cloak, petitioner in red) following hierarchical conventions; green used for attendant to create secondary depth; white highlights applied over pigments for fabric folds; floor tiles alternate pink and red with black diaper pattern for visual rhythm.

features: King elevated on throne above supplicant
Diagonal gaze and gestural line from petitioner to monarch
Overlapping footstool and throne for depth
Armorial bearings and helmet superimposed in upper register to balance lower action

decorative_elements: Heraldic shield (blue field with black reeds) and helmet crest overhead

drawing_technique.line_style: Crisp quill-pen outlines in dark brown ink with varied line weight for figures and drapery edges
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal cross-hatching; subtle white pigment highlights on garments to indicate volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without true linear perspective; overlapping elements (throne, footstool, figures) imply depth

content_theme.scene_description: A single full-page scene depicting a feudal investiture or charter presentation. Three figures occupy the space: on the left, a crowned king clad in ultramarine blue cloak over a vermilion tunic sits on a gilded throne with matching footstool. He extends his right hand in a pointing gesture and holds the upper edge of a parchment charter, whose lower edge bears a round pendent seal showing a rampant lion. Kneeling to the right of the throne, a young nobleman in a long red robe gazes up respectfully and holds the charter with both hands. Behind him stands an attendant in a green gown, right hand raised in acquiescence and left hand resting on the noble’s shoulder, indicating support. The throne’s elevation and gold frame emphasize the monarch’s preeminence. The floor is decorated with alternating pink and red tiles bearing black diaper motifs. Above the figures float a steel helmet with green-tipped black feather crest and, to its right, a heraldic shield (blue field, black reeds on a sable chief) signifying the petitioner’s lineage. Decorative border and armorial devices reinforce the legal and dynastic context of this investiture ceremony.

secular: Crowned king in blue cloak and vermilion tunic seated on gilded throne
Kneeling nobleman in red robe holding charter with pendent seal
Attendant in green gown with raised hand

objects: Steel helmet with black and green plume

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth flesh side with faint hair follicle pattern; regular quaternion gathering indicated by consistent gutter margins.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation; slight flaking of vermilion at edges of red robe; gold leaf remains burnished; no significant water staining; evidence of modern conservation lining at lower margin.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf on frame and throne
Fine underdrawing visible under UV light, especially in drapery folds
Plummet ruling visible faintly around margins
Punchwork decoration under crown and border gold

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Institutional use (royal chancery or court record)

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature likely originates from a late 13th- or early 14th-century French chancery or court workshop, produced under a royal patron’s direction to record and legitimize feudal grants. The emphasis on burnished gold, ultramarine and vermilion reflects high material investment, underscoring the political significance of the charter presentation. The heraldic device—blue field charged with reeds—and corresponding helmet crest situate the petitioner within a specific noble lineage, while the king’s elevated throne and pointing gesture reinforce monarchical authority. Stylistically, the crisp outlines, minimal shading and formalized floor diaper pattern align with the mature Gothic illumination traditions of Paris and the Île-de-France region, though the simplified drapery may indicate a provincial atelier influenced by the Channel School. Underdrawing visible under UV suggests planning by a master illuminator, with execution by assistants in color application. Iconographically, the scene asserts the reciprocal bond of fealty and royal favor, serving both documentary and propagandistic functions. Compared to contemporaneous manuscripts such as the Liber Regalis or regional cartularies, this image integrates narrative naturalism with heraldic clarity, merging traditional investiture iconography with distinctive armorial display. The work thus embodies the intersection of legal record, visual diplomacy and courtly art practice in medieval France.
